title: Mum's two sons were 'saved from potential abduction' thanks to two words she taught them
text:
Lifestyle Mum's two sons were 'saved from potential abduction' thanks to two words she taught them "Their story of what had transpired while I had stupidly left them out there alone made me simultaneously sick and grateful" Share There's a new idea for teaching kids to be safe (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily   
A mum said she felt sick after her two young sons explained a terrifying incident which compromised their safety - then grateful that they had remembered two words which got them out of harm's way. 
Jodie Norton explained on her blog, Time Well Spent , how she had been in the shower in the morning when she felt an unbearable, stabbing pain in her abdomen, leaving her doubled over, light-headed and nauseous. 
She somehow managed to get dressed and drove to the local hospital with her four kids, leaving her two oldest boys - aged 10 and eight - outside of the A&E department on a bench so they could wait for a neighbour to pick them up and take them to school, as her parents had arranged. 
It wasn't until later she found out that the neighbour was coming from somewhere further away than his house and took 40 minutes instead of five. 
During that time, her two boys had been approached by three strangers several times who had tried to persuade them to go into a hospital bathroom with a man. 
"Their story of what had transpired while I had stupidly left them out there alone made me simultaneously sick and grateful," she said. Instagram 
"While on that bench, they were approached by an adult female and two punk males who asked them if they’d #help them out by going into the bathroom where her boyfriend was hiding from the doctor and see if they could convince him to come out and get treated.'" 
The mum explained how her 10-year-old, CJ, replied 'no, thank you' but they kept asking him, saying: 'Please? You could really save his life if you'd just go in that bathroom and tell him it's safe to come out.' 
Luckily, CJ continued to forcefully tell them no and they finally gave up. Instagram 
Before the neighbour arrived to pick up the boys, they saw a third man emerge from the hospital bathroom, jump into a car with the other strangers and drive away. 
Jodie said her mouth "hung open" the whole time her sons were telling her the story - but her anger turned to gratitude when they explained why they hadn't gone off with the strangers. 
"I heard CJ spout off a family 'stay safe' rule we went over way too long ago that helped him know these creeps were up to no good. Most specifically, a tip for identifying a 'tricky person'." 
CJ had said: "Mom, I knew they were tricky people because they were asking us for help. Adults don’t ask kids for help.” What is the 'tricky people' concept? 
The 'tricky person' or 'tricky people' concept was created by Safely Ever After . Founder Pattie Fitzgerald advises: "Stop telling your kids not to talk to strangers. They might need to talk to a stranger one day. 
"Instead, teach them which sorts of strangers are safe." 
One of the things the program encourages parents to teach kids is that only 'tricky people' ask kids for help. If a safe adult needs help, they'll ask another adult - not a child. 
She also advises: :"Replace the word 'stranger' with 'tricky person'. It's not what someone looks like, it's what they say or want to do with a child that makes them unsafe or 'tricky'. 
"A tricky person can be someone you know well, don't know at all or know just a little bit. Like your mail carrier or the ice cream man. Anyone who tries to get a child to break their safety rules or hurt their body is not OK." 
Pattie has many other prevention tips and 'red flags' on the Safely Ever After website. 
Jodie has notified police of the incident and they are reviewing CCTV footage outside the hospital. Like us on Facebook
